lesson.page: In this game you have to mix three colours to produce a target colour. There are two parts: Light and paint.

In the first part, light, you control the brightness of three spotlights - one of each of the primary colours - red, green and blue. Mixing different amounts of these three colours can make every other colour.
Here, a red colour is made of just red light.
Here, we make yellow from a mixture of red and green light. Red and blue light make magenta (pink). Green and blue light make cyan (turquoise).
Equal amounts of all three colours at maximum brightness (100%) will produce white light, or grey if the brightness is lowered.
If there isn't much difference between the brightness of the three colours, the result is often a pale shade of the brighter colour. Here the green is slightly brighter than the red and blue.
The darker a colour, the less light is used - so the lower the brightness level of the spotlight.
Use the sliders to change the brightness of the red, green and blue spotlights. When the colour of the central triangle matches the target, you've won. If you need help click the 'Hint' button.
In the second part, we use splodges of paint rather than light. There are three colours - cyan, magenta and yellow.

Each paint colour is the opposite of a light colour - here, cyan is a mixture of blue and green. Cyan paint is the opposite of red light - it absorbs red light, but reflects blue and green.Similarly, magenta is the opposite of green, and yellow is the opposite of blue.
When we combine paint colours, we absorb all the light the paints absorb. A mixture of cyan and yellow paint reflects only green light and appears green.
A mixture of cyan and magenta is blue. A mixture of magenta and yellow is red.

If we use a little paint, the the colour produced is quite light, as we don't absorb much light. A mixture of equal amounts of all three colours absorbs all three primary colours and is therefore grey or black.
